message: Happy New Year! 2017 promises to be a year of change in our nation. What are you looking forward to this year?
We’re going to get a lot done these next two years. We’re going to be fighting for jobs, get people back to work, get coal back on its feet, invest in infrastructure, and take care of our seniors.
Honored to have my family by my side as I took the oath of office. I am proud to call West Virginia our home.

We must honor the work of West Virginia’s coal miners by protecting the pensions and healthcare benefits they worked their whole lives to earn. I’m not giving up the fight to shore up our miners’ pensions.

I sat down with Charlie Boothe of the Bluefield Daily Telegraph Official Page to talk about how I’ll be working with our new president, Donald Trump, on a new direction for West Virginia and our nation.  “These last eight years have been devastating economically for West Virginia,” Jenkins said. “I am optimistic we can get the policy right so we get coal back on its feet and create job opportunities.”
The right of the people to keep and bear arms shall not be infringed. I read these important words on the House floor today during our reading of the Constitution.

I’ve reintroduced my legislation to ensure that black lung benefits are preserved and protected as we replace Obamacare. Our miners deserve better than the failing, costly, broken Obamacare system we have now, and we need to replace it before it completely collapses. I will fight to make sure any replacement for Obamacare includes the Byrd amendment for our miners and their families.

The Obama administration made a grave error in allowing the United Nations Security Council to pass a dangerous, anti-Israel resolution. That’s why I cosponsored and voted today to pass legislation responding to the United Nations, rejecting this resolution, and supporting our ally of Israel. I will continue to support policies that protect our friends and allies in the Middle East.

From today’s The Register-Herald (Official): In the mist of Republican plans to repeal the Affordable Care Act, Rep. Evan Jenkins, R-W.Va., reintroduced a resolution Thursday to protect black lung benefits from such an act.
Headed into the House Chamber for the counting of the Electoral College votes and certification of Donald Trump as our next president. Truly a historic day!
House Democrats just objected to the Electoral College results from West Virginia. The voices of West Virginians need to be heard and respected, not used for a political ploy.
WVVA News has a look at a bill I helped pass, the REINS Act, that will give West Virginians a voice in approving or rejecting new regulations.
Our men and women in blue put their lives on the line for us. On this National Law Enforcement Appreciation Day, thank an officer for keeping us safe!

Investment in water infrastructure is crucial for West Virginia’s rural communities. We need to plan ahead to make sure our sewer systems can adequately and reliably serve our homes, businesses, schools and hospitals. I supported increasing funding for the Appalachian Regional Commission because this money directly benefits West Virginians and improves our state’s infrastructure.

A painting that depicts police officers in a derogatory, inflammatory way has no business being displayed in our nation’s Capitol building. The rules of the Congressional Art Competition prohibit content like this, and I am disappointed that House Democrats rehung this offensive painting today. Our police officers deserve our thanks and appreciation for their work, not being insulted in this way.

I’m honored to serve on the House Appropriations Committee for the next two years and to continue my work for West Virginia. I’ll make sure our state gets the funding we need to address our priorities, including rural health care, the drug crisis, black lung clinics, highways, veterans, and infrastructure. West Virginia’s priorities are my priorities, and I am proud to fight for our state on the Appropriations Committee.
It’s common sense that the Obama administration’s war on coal has cost West Virginia jobs. Now, the EPA will have to answer for just how many jobs it has killed through overregulation.

I’m asking President-elect Trump to work with us to help lower prescription drug prices as we repeal and replace Obamacare. No one should have to decide between buying needed prescription medication and putting food on the table, and we must ensure affordable healthcare coverage for everyone. You can click below to read my letter to the president-elect.
NA

Today my Service Academy Board and I interviewed 10 talented West Virginia students for nominations to our nation's military academy. We were honored to be joined by World War II Medal of Honor Recipient Woody Williams as we selected the next generation of leaders.
Inauguration Day in West Virginia is a day to rededicate ourselves to working together for a better future for the people of our beloved state.

Wayne High School - WV students in Mr. Thompson and Mr. Ross’ civics classes are studying the presidency, so I stopped by to talk to them about the inauguration and how I’m working for our district in Congress. I stayed for lunch – taco salad – and the chance to spend some more time with these terrific students.

Habitat for Humanity’s Veterans Housing Initiative is helping veterans become homeowners. I had the chance to tour the Veterans Village, meet with one of these homeowners, and see this great work for our veterans firsthand.
Sending President George H.W. Bush and Barbara Bush prayers and best wishes for a speedy recovery.
West Virginians are arriving to pick up their tickets for tomorrow’s inauguration! If you’re in town for the inauguration, come by my office – 1609 Longworth – and say hi. We’d love to see you!
More West Virginians have stopped by to pick up their inauguration tickets – the Runyon and Spry families.
I’m ready to welcome Donald Trump as our next president! Like and share if you are too. #inauguration
The excitement is building as we walk out to the platform – we’re just an hour or so away from the start of the #inauguration.
It’s official: Our new president, Donald Trump. Congratulations, Mr. President.
Great vantage point for the First Family's walk down Pennsylvania Avenue to the White House.
Change is coming -- in his first day in office, President Trump has stopped all pending regulations. This gives the people a voice in whether these regulations should -- or should not -- go forward.

We need policies that put American workers and jobs first. Any trade deal needs to be in the best interests of American families, and I’m glad to see the Trans-Pacific Partnership stopped in its tracks.
Great meeting today with Becky Gooch Erbacher and Lori Milam of the West Virginia Head Start Association. I am proud of the hard work they and their colleagues do to educate West Virginia’s children.
Taxpayers should not be paying for abortions. I’m proud to be pro-life, and I voted today to help pass the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act.
Securing our borders makes our nation safer. The president’s actions today will help protect our national security, crack down on illegal immigration, and open up jobs for Americans.

While we absolutely need to bring back our coal jobs, we also need to train workers in new skills so they can provide for their families. I’ve introduced a bill to help diversify our economy, retrain displaced coal miners, and attract new industries to West Virginia.

I just spoke with Vice President Pence about the importance of creating jobs in West Virginia, particularly for our miners and our hard-hit coal communities. I shared with him that several coal mines are expected to reopen soon, and I invited him and President Trump to come to West Virginia and cut the ribbon at a coal mine and support our miners. President Trump will be arriving soon to speak to members of Congress, and I look forward to hearing from him.
Our coal miners getting a standing ovation from our president and Congress today.

We’re making strides in helping newborns born drug-exposed, but there’s still so much left to be done. That’s why I’m asking President Trump’s Health and Human Services secretary nominee to prioritize treating these babies as he drafts next year’s budget. Every baby deserves a chance at a healthy and happy start to life.
Too many regulations are costing us jobs and making it harder for small businesses to expand. We’ll be eliminating excessive regulations to grow our economy and create opportunities for everyone.

I’m proud to join House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy, House Natural Resources Committee Chairman Rep. Rob Bishop, and Reps. Bill Johnson and David McKinley to lead the way in stopping one of the Obama administration’s last job-killing, anti-coal regulations.

President Trump’s selection of Judge Gorsuch for the U.S. Supreme Court is a sound and conservative choice. In his more than a decade as a federal judge, he has demonstrated a respect for the letter of the law, the intent of our Founding Fathers, and the ideals of our Constitution. I hope the Senate will act quickly to confirm him and fill this vacancy in our nation’s highest court.

From the Daily Mail Opinion page of the Charleston Gazette-Mail:   Having lost thousands of coal jobs over those eight years, West Virginians could not afford yet another federal effort to close mines and put miners out of work. But that’s exactly what the stream buffer zone rule would do — and why Congress is putting a stop to it.
The House has just passed the Johnson-Jenkins-McKinley resolution to protect our coal jobs – and it looks like the Senate will take it up later this evening.

As go the roads, so go the jobs. The FAST Act I helped to pass includes $2.5 billion for West Virginia’s roads, and I met with the King Coal Highway Authority about how we can work with the state to make sure West Virginia’s highway needs are funded.
Speaker Paul Ryan has signed our legislation to stop a job-killing, anti-coal rule, and it’s on its way to the White House to become law.

I was proud to nominate eight West Virginia students to our nation’s service academies, including Josh Siemiaczko of Mercer County. I’m thankful that these young people are ready to step up, serve our nation, and become the next generation of leaders.

I’m urging our state leaders and legislators to act now to prioritize southern West Virginia’s roads, including the King Coal Highway. As the Bluefield Daily Telegraph said today, “Federal funding is available. Now is the time to act.”

It was an honor to meet with General Robert Neller, commandant of the Marine Corps, to discuss critical funding needs. As a member of the Appropriations Committee's Military Construction subcommittee, I will make sure our troops have the resources they need to fulfill their missions.

By working together, we can help people find recovery and combat substance abuse. I spoke at the CADCA Community Anti-Drug Coalitions of America’s national conference today and met with West Virginians making a difference. #CADCAForum
When we get our coal miners working again, we get West Virginia working again.

Our miners are the backbone of West Virginia, and I thanked the hardworking miners at the Republic Energy mine in Fayette County today for all they do for our nation. I’m fighting for them in Congress, helping to introduce and pass legislation that stops an Obama regulation – one that would have killed one third of all coal jobs. We’re getting things done so they can keep mining the coal that powers our nation and grows our economy.

I’ve recently met with West Virginians about investing in public safety, expanding access to health care in rural West Virginia, increasing funding for rural drinking water programs, and improving educational and library resources for the visually impaired.
I joined the County Commissioners Association of West Virginia this morning to talk about how I’m fighting for West Virginia jobs and ways to diversify our economy.

Too many veterans have given their all for our country but are unable to find work after leaving the military. I voted last night to pass the HIRE Vets Act to promote hiring veterans. I hope West Virginia’s businesses will consider hiring more veterans and give them a chance to succeed.

The black lung benefits program is a promise to our miners – a promise we must keep. I’ve introduced legislation to affirm our commitment to protecting the Byrd amendment and these critical black lung benefits as we draft healthcare reform.
STARTING SOON: I’m at the White House with President Trump as he signs a bill to protect our coal jobs and stop a job-killing rule.
President Trump is standing by his promise to help West Virginia and our miners. I’m proud to support him as he signs our bill to save one-third of all coal jobs.
This is a great day for our coal miners, for our jobs, for our state. President Trump is keeping his word, and I am proud to stand with our miners.
Happy Presidents Day! Which president inspires you the most and why?
I had a wonderful discussion today with seniors at the Barboursville Senior Center about safeguarding Social Security and strengthening Medicare.
Talking with the West Virginia Coal Association about how I’m working to bring back coal jobs and diversify our economy by redeveloping former mine sites.

This morning I sat down with members of the West Virginia House Judiciary Committee to talk about how we can work together to combat the drug crisis. By increasing funding and holding federal and state agencies accountable, we can make a difference.

I hosted a grant symposium in Charleston today to help county and city governments and nonprofits learn more about funding available to fight the drug crisis. More than 70 local leaders joined us to hear from federal and state agencies about grants available for treatment, prevention and law enforcement programs. By working together, we can make a difference and help people find recovery.
Coal has made this nation great. The Coal Heritage Museum in Boone County celebrates coal -- and the people who mine it.
We can expand tourism and attractions like the Hatfield-McCoy Trails to diversify our economy. Thanks to the Madison Rotary Club for a great discussion on this important issue.
Stopped by Cornerstone Family Interventions, Inc. in Madison to learn more about their work to help and support families in Boone and Lincoln counties.
I’m looking forward to hearing President Trump talk about creating jobs in West Virginia and across the country during tonight’s #JointAddress. What are you hoping to hear?

President Trump shared with our nation a bold vision to spur job creation and bring businesses back to America, one that will grow our economy and help families struggling to make ends meet. It’s time for our nation to come together to support our president, to work together, and to unite behind policies and solutions to improve the lives of all Americans. I look forward to working with the president to bring more jobs and opportunities to West Virginia, and I firmly believe that our state and our nation’s best days lie ahead.
Meeting with UMWA miners today to discuss how we can protect and preserve the healthcare benefits that our miners have earned.

If you are one of the tens of thousands of West Virginians without power – stay safe! To report an outage or for more information, call Appalachian Power at 877-237-2886, Mon Power at 800-686-0022, or Potomac Edison at 800-686-0011.  Remember – never touch or drive over downed lines!
On this day in 1961, Marshall College officially became Marshall University! Happy anniversary to a great West Virginia institution.

It is always an honor to sit down with our veterans service organizations to discuss their priorities and the needs of our veterans. I welcomed both the American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars to my office this week and am committed to ensuring our veterans have the care and benefits they have earned.

The West Virginia Wing of the Civil Air Patrol played a key role in responding to last year’s floods in West Virginia, helping us use aerial views to survey and record flood damage. I met with them today about how we can continue to fund their important work.

This week, I’ve voted to pass legislation to help cut unneeded regulations and rein in wasteful federal spending. The SCRUB Act helps identify unnecessary and burdensome regulations that can be eliminated, saving taxpayers money. And the Regulatory Integrity Act will prevent federal agencies from using taxpayer dollars to lobby for proposed regulations. Both of these bills will help us create jobs by cutting regulations that are holding our economy back.

Today I brought together leaders in Montgomery to talk about the town’s future, the transition of the WVU Tech campus to KVC, and how I can help with any federal issues. Thank you to KVC Health Systems, West Virginia University, BridgeValley Community & Technical College, the Fayette County Commission, the Kanawha County Commission, the YMCA, and the Montgomery mayor’s office for joining me for this important discussion.

Our miners worked their whole lives for their pensions and healthcare benefits, and we need to ensure they receive what they were promised. I sat down with UMWA miners and retirees in Beckley whose benefits are in jeopardy to hear their stories and share how I’m fighting to pass a solution to preserve these critical benefits.
WSAZ NewsChannel 3 has a look at my visit to Montgomery and how we can repurpose the WVU Tech campus to grow the town.

I am carefully reading and reviewing the American Health Care Act to make sure it meets the needs of West Virginians, which includes empowering families to make their own healthcare choices, protecting patients with pre-existing conditions, and ensuring access to care for low-income individuals. We must make sure people are protected with a reasonable transition period and that patients and doctors have time to choose the plans that work for them.   Americans deserve access to health care that is truly affordable, allows them to make choices that fit their needs, and keeps Washington out of the doctor-patient relationship – all of which Obamacare has failed to deliver. As we go through this open and transparent process, I am fully committed to reforming our healthcare system to empower patients, lower costs, and make health insurance affordable.

I am carefully reviewing the American Health Care Act to decide if it is in the best interests of West Virginians. After discussing with committees, I am proud to share that the Byrd amendment is protected and this bill does not change the eligibility presumption for black lung benefits. Since coming to Congress, I have fought to protect this program by introducing legislation and advocating to House leaders. Our miners and their widows deserve these critical benefits, and I will continue to fight for them.

I am carefully reading and reviewing the American Health Care Act to make sure it meets the needs of West Virginians, and I encourage you to do the same. Visit my website to read the full text of the bill and learn more about how it will lower healthcare costs and expand coverage. This bill does not change the Byrd amendment and the eligibility presumption for black lung benefits, and it preserves coverage for pre-existing conditions and people younger than 26.
I was honored to welcome West Virginia members of Paralyzed Veterans of America to my office today, where we talked about the need for a strong VA system and access to care for spinal cord injuries.
Congress needs to act now to protect pensions and healthcare benefits for retired miners like Preston Thomas of Raleigh County.

This week, I voted to fully fund a program that’s keeping $12 billion in illegal drugs off our streets – the National Guard’s Counter-Drug program. I’m proud to support programs like this that are helping our law enforcement stop drug trafficking.
Good luck to The Herd in the C-USA Championship tonight!

I’ve recently welcomed West Virginians and leaders of our nation’s military to Washington to discuss critical issues: national security, live-saving medical research, and funding for youth development and community programs.
I was honored to join West Virginians at the State Capitol today to stand up for life. I’m proud to be pro-life and to defend the unborn.

I brought new Huntington Chamber President Bill Bissett to Lily's Place so he could see their good work firsthand and learn more about how Huntington is coming together to help the most vulnerable victims of the drug crisis -- babies born exposed to opioids.

Speaking with West Virginia physicians with the American Congress of Obstetricians and Gynecologists about their priorities, including the Preventing Maternal Deaths Act to help reduce deaths due to pregnancy complications.
After an unusually warm winter, it's nice to see some snow on Capitol Hill!
I really enjoyed giving this great group of students, parents and teachers from Christian Faith Academy in Van a nighttime tour of the Capitol! Have a safe trip back to Boone County.

Hearing the thoughts and experiences of West Virginians is important to me -- share your opinions below on the American Health Care Act. If you haven’t read the bill, you can visit my website to read it for yourself.

The VA must be focused on serving our veterans. I helped to pass the VA Accountability First Act today, which will make it easier to remove any VA employee for poor performance or misconduct. There are many good people at the VA who are dedicated to caring for our veterans, and this bill will ensure they can do their work in a productive environment.
Join me in congratulating Pocahontas County’s own Tyler Owens, who has been admitted to the U.S. Air Force Academy. I was proud to nominate him to the academy and know he will serve our country well.

Ensuring our veterans have the best health care means making sure they’re being treated by the best medical staff possible. I helped pass legislation today, H.R. 1367, that will help the VA recruit and keep the best doctors, nurses and other professionals.

Proud parents at today's Officer Candidates School graduation and commissioning ceremony in Quantico, Va. We pray for our son's safety and are humbled by his desire to serve our country as an officer in the United States Marine Corps.
I welcomed many West Virginians to my office last week to talk about a variety of issues, including the importance of faith and prayer in our daily lives.
Thank you to the West Virginia TRIO Association for stopping by today to talk about how we can help first-generation college students succeed.

I'm continuing to fight for the pensions and benefits our miners earned through years of hard work in our mines. I met with UMWA miners about this critical issue -- we can't forget about our miners and their widows.
Spending the afternoon on the phone listening to the thoughts and concerns of West Virginians.
Today’s Keystone pipeline announcement shows how committed President Trump is to growing jobs and getting America back to work again.

I would like to thank each and every West Virginian in the Third District who called, emailed or reached out to my office to share their thoughts on the healthcare bill. I heard your voices and want you to know your opinions are very important to me. I look forward to continuing to work with President Trump and my colleagues in Congress on solutions to make a difference in West Virginia – to create jobs, to diversify our economy, to address the drug crisis, and to make healthcare truly affordable for everyone.

Today I joined Vice President Pence and Small Business Administrator Linda McMahon in Charleston and Putnam County to celebrate small business success stories. President Trump and his team are working to create jobs in West Virginia and across our country.
Welcoming the Dornbos family of Culloden to my office before their Capitol tour! Are you planning a trip to DC in the coming months? Call my office at 202-225-3452 for a Capitol tour.

The RECLAIM Act can be and should be part of the solution to revitalize our coalfields, diversify the economy, and create jobs for West Virginians. I’m proud to support this bill to bring nearly $200 million to West Virginia to help put our former mine sites back to work for us.

After eight years of radical environmental policies from the White House, we now have a president focused on bringing coal jobs back. President Trump signed an executive order today that will help stop the war on coal and bring hope and jobs back to West Virginia. I’m proud to stand with our president to support our miners and our families.

Thanks to Rabbi Victor Urecki and West Virginia AIPAC members for an engaging discussion on the shared interests of the U.S. and Israel. Israel is our strongest ally in the Middle East, and we must continue to strengthen our partnership with Israel.

Alzheimer’s touches nearly every family – but together, we can #EndAlz. Thanks to the Alzheimer's Association, West Virginia Chapter for stopping by to share their stories and how we can support research for a cure.

Thanks to the HONEST ACT, everyone will now have access to the science and research the EPA is using to make decisions – something we’ve never had before. The EPA can’t use secret science and studies anymore to try to justify killing our coal jobs.

I joined Huntington Mayor Steve Williams today to talk about how the Appalachian Regional Commission is supporting Huntington's redevelopment. The ARC recently awarded Huntington a $750,000 grant for a brownfield redevelopment project, a job-creating cornerstone of the town's America's Best Communities campaign. The ARC works for West Virginia, and I will continue to fight for its future.
These RAZE middle school students from Wyoming County visited the State Capitol today for Tobacco-Free Day.

Great to see so many good friends at the State Capitol today – Senate President Mitch Carmichael, Senator Greg Boso of Nicholas County, Senator Mark Maynard of Wayne County, Senator Patricia Rucker of Jefferson County, Senator Dave Sypolt of Preston County, Agriculture Commissioner Kent Leonhardt, and former Senator Daniel Hall.

More help is on the way to fix roads damaged by recent floods. These federal grants – more than $34 million – will go a long way to help reconnect communities and repair damaged or destroyed roads. I will continue to work with our state and federal officials to make sure West Virginia receives the assistance we need to rebuild.

We pause to remember and honor the 29 fathers, sons, brothers and friends we lost at Upper Big Branch seven years ago today. Every mining family prays for their loved one to come home at the end of each shift, and we pray for peace and strength for these 29 families. We must do all we can to ensure the safety of each and every miner, and we will never forget those we lost on this sad day.

A House subcommittee heard today how the RECLAIM Act will spur a new era of investment and revitalization in West Virginia and beyond. By redeveloping former mine sites like the one in Nicholas County pictured below, we can diversify our economy, attract new industries, and provide good jobs for West Virginians. I am hopeful that the committee will consider this legislation quickly and send it to the House floor for a vote.

Teresa Anderson’s father asked her to protect the benefits he earned through decades in the mines so they’d be there for her mother, Mary. We cannot let the clock run out on our miners and their families. They kept up their end of the bargain – now it’s time for us to do the same.

WV MetroNews looks at how the RECLAIM Act will help create jobs right here in West Virginia. We can harness the potential of former mine sites to create jobs and attract new businesses to our great state.
Congratulations to Judge Neil Gorsuch, who will defend our nation’s Constitution and rule of law as an associate justice of the U.S. Supreme Court.

Please join me in congratulating Clay Havens of Union, who has been admitted to the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis. I had the pleasure to meet with him in January as I considered who to nominate for admission to our service academies, and I know he will make us proud as he joins our nation’s armed services.
Visiting with Beckley Mayor Rob Rappold to talk about key issues in Raleigh County, including creating new jobs and opportunities for WVU Tech to partner with the community.
No taxpayer dollars should go toward supporting abortion – that’s why we need to pass the Defunding Planned Parenthood Act.

Blackhawk Mining is holding a job fair for coal miners tomorrow – April 12 – from 7 a.m. to 6 p.m. at the Country Inn and Suites in Beckley. Applicants should bring resumes and their mining certifications to the job fair.
Meeting with constituents in Huntington about how I’m committed to conservative values and working with President Trump to create jobs in West Virginia.

Great turnout at the Blackhawk Mining job fair at the Country Inn and Suites in Beckley today. My staff stopped by this morning to meet with the miners ready to get to work – miners like Jerry, Blaine and Chad. If you are a miner looking for work, bring your resume and mining certification until 6 p.m. tonight to apply for mining jobs.

The Bluefield Daily Telegraph Official Page looks at why Congress needs to pass legislation I helped introduce, the RECLAIM Act.   “While the coal industry may be showing renewed signs of life here in the mountains of southern West Virginia and Southwest Virginia, efforts to diversify our regional economy and create new jobs must continue.”
Coal jobs are continuing to come back. If you’re a miner looking for work, United Coal Co. is holding a job fair from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. Friday, April 14, at Tamarack in Beckley.

I’m proud to defend our Second Amendment and the rights of law-abiding Americans. That’s why I’ve introduced the Protecting the Second Amendment Act, which ensures the government can’t infringe of the rights of responsible Americans to keep firearms.

Emily Kinner of Huntington, a student at Marshall University, represented our state as West Virginia’s Cherry Blossom Princess at this year’s Cherry Blossom Festival in Washington. Congratulations, Emily!

Congratulations to Joshua Siemiaczko of Bluefield, who has been admitted to the U.S. Military Academy at West Point. I am grateful for his willingness to serve our nation in uniform and know he will represent us all well as he pursues his education at West Point.
Wishing you and your family a blessed Easter. He Has Risen!
I always enjoy welcoming West Virginians to my offices to hear their thoughts and concerns about issues important to them. Here’s a look at some recent groups who have visited with me.

Today I brought together leaders in Huntington to discuss an innovative project to help treat babies born exposed to drugs. This center, which is still in the planning stages, would focus on helping families and these children from birth to kindergarten. Participants included Marshall President Jerry Gilbert, Appalachia HIDTA's Kenny Burner, and Public Health Commissioner Dr. Rahul Gupta, whom I took to Lily's Place before our meeting.
My colleagues and I have a message for congressional leaders: Protect our retired miners and their families. Keep the promise. Act now to secure the health care our miners earned.

I joined Raleigh County seniors today to celebrate the Raleigh County Commission on Aging senior center, which is now the first and only West Virginia senior center to be accredited. This is a big honor for them, and I was glad to join them for the festivities!
At ABB Inc. in Greenbrier County, I talked with employees about the importance of manufacturing in West Virginia and how we can diversify our economy by attracting more manufacturers.

Stopped by Central City Café to grab a quick bite after yesterday’s meetings in Huntington. This family-run small business has been serving Central City in Huntington for 20 years. Always good to see Dave and Sherry Luther!
Today’s the day – looking forward to Huntington being named America’s Best Community!

We can help Make America Great Again by making more in America and buying more that’s made in America. I applaud President Trump’s executive order to help grow our economy and create more jobs for American workers.

Huntington wins first place in the America’s Best Communities competition! I’m incredibly proud of the plan put forth by Huntington and wholeheartedly believe that our best days lie ahead. This is a great day for Huntington and a celebration of all that the Jewel City has to offer.
Cenergy in Milton is creating jobs in West Virginia, thanks to the growing domestic energy market. We can use natural gas and coal to create both secure, affordable energy and more jobs here at home.

Big news for Marshall University today – $2.8 million in grants from the U.S. Economic Development Administration and the Appalachian Regional Commission. I was so pleased to join them today for the announcement and to vote for the funding for this important grant, which will help Marshall’s RCBI provide training and support for new and existing small businesses. Diversifying our economy and attracting new industries is the key to creating new jobs in West Virginia.

I joined Alderson residents today to commemorate the 90th anniversary of FPC Alderson and thanked the employees for all of their hard work during last summer’s floods. The employees helped staff the town’s command center, cleaned up debris, and worked to conserve the town’s water supply.

Today, I brought together local and state leaders, federal agencies, industry experts, researchers and scientists in Charleston to look at how elements found in coal could be used to grow our economy. Rare earth elements are abundant in coal, and they are used in many technologies and products today. Thanks to everyone who attended to discuss this exciting prospect for Appalachia.
Stopped by West Virginia American Water to meet with employees about the important work they do.
Meeting some of the next generation of leaders of West Virginia – third graders from Hamlin PK-8 School visiting our beautiful State Capitol.

Today’s town hall in Hamlin touched on a number of important topics – health care, miners’ pensions and benefits, and infrastructure. Thank you to everyone who attended and shared their thoughts with me.

During a meeting with seniors in Salt Rock, I assured them that I’m committed to protecting their Social Security and Medicare. Our seniors worked hard for these programs and deserve the benefits they’ve earned.
Our miners earned their benefits – it’s time to keep the promise and protect them!

We’ve got to get King Coal Highway built – and one of the key stretches runs through Buffalo Mountain. Today in Washington, I brought together local, state, private-sector and federal leaders – including Senator Shelley Moore Capito – to identify roadblocks and ways we can get this project moving again. As go the roads, so go the jobs!
These Barboursville Middle School students got a behind-the-scenes tour of the Capitol last night – including a visit to the House Chamber!

Very productive meeting today with EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt. He is committed to returning the EPA to its core missions without the regulatory overreaches that put thousands of hardworking West Virginians out of work. Administrator Pruitt said today that the “war on coal is over,” and I’ve invited him to visit our great state. This video makes a powerful point about the new direction of the EPA. https://www.epa.gov/newsroom/epa-administrator-scott-pruitt-back-basics-agenda
Saturday is National Prescription Drug Take-Back Day, a chance for you to dispose of unneeded or expired medications safely. Learn more and find a location near you.

After eight years of radical environmental policies from the White House, we now have a president focused on bringing coal jobs back. The so-called Clean Power Plan is one of the Obama administration’s key anti-coal policies, and I will continue to support President Trump and his administration in stopping this rule.
My staff attended UPS’ fishing event for veterans at Little Beaver State Park on Friday. Veterans, thank you for your service!

Today we took action to protect our retired coal miners from having their health benefits run out. We must now pass the permanent fix our miners were promised and deserve. I've been working directly with Speaker Ryan, the leadership team, and our colleagues in the Senate to see that this gets done. Real progress was made this week, and we are closer than ever before to getting a permanent fix put into law. I firmly believe a solution that can get the votes to pass has been identified, and hopefully we can have it put up for a vote next week. Miners worked their whole lives to secure these benefits and are only asking for what they have earned. We have to keep our promise to them, and I will continue to work each and every day to help protect our miners.

We have reached an agreement for a permanent solution to secure miners' benefits and provide them the peace of mind they deserve. We will vote later this week to pass this fix and put to rest this issue.   I have heard from countless mining families worried about losing these crucial benefits. These miners worked their whole lives to make our country truly great, and they deserve these hard-earned benefits. They aren’t asking for a handout or a bailout, just what they were promised. Their voices have been heard loud and clear, and we are keeping the promise.  I worked closely with House Speaker Paul Ryan and our leadership to ensure a permanent solution was reached, and I thank him on behalf of all of our miners and their families for his commitment to protecting these benefits.

Joe Reynolds and Brett Dillon are two retired West Virginia miners who have been fighting to protect the benefits they earned. Tomorrow, I'll vote to pass a permanent fix to save their benefits and keep the promise.
Good news for West Virginia: Coal production is up, demand is increasing, and jobs are growing.

In less than an hour, I’ll be voting to increase funding for the Appalachian Regional Commission and other economic development programs. These programs are making significant investments in West Virginia, providing grants for infrastructure, economic development, diversification, and more. I’m proud to support the ARC and other key rural investment programs.

Our miners were made a promise, and today, I voted to keep that promise. This legislation includes the permanent fix for our miners’ benefits, a fix I have been working with Speaker Paul Ryan to make a reality. This is yet another victory for West Virginia in this Congress and a great day for our miners and their families.

I’m saddened by the news from Yeager Airport this morning and send my prayers and condolences to the friends and family of the crew. I’ve reached out to the airport and to federal agencies to offer any assistance they may need and will continue to monitor the situation closely.
In the Huntington Herald-Dispatch, I talked about how I’ll keep fighting to protect programs that are helping West Virginia fight the drug crisis.

I joined U.S. Health and Human Services Secretary Tom Price and other administration officials in Charleston today for an important discussion on how West Virginia is fighting back against the opioid crisis. I shared with him how we are leading the way in improving care for babies born drug exposed, thanks to Lily’s Place in Huntington, as well as my commitment to support funding for treatment as a member of the House Appropriations Committee. I thank Secretary Price for visiting our state and for taking the best practices from West Virginia back to the White House.
NA

My two sons are Eagle Scouts, and I’ve seen firsthand the lessons and values that Scouting instills in our young people. I was proud to attend the Annual Friends of Scouting Adena District Luncheon in Huntington and thank our local Scouting leaders for their hard work.
I’m asking the Drug Enforcement Agency to re-evaluate its quota system for opioid production to make sure we never see another drug crisis like this again.

Please join me in congratulating Hunter White of Point Pleasant, who was been admitted to the U.S. Naval Academy. I had the pleasure of nominating Hunter to the academy and know he will make us proud as he prepares to serve our nation in uniform. Congratulations, Hunter!

This Police Week, we honor those lost in the line of duty and thank those who put their lives at risk to keep us safe. I was honored to be invited to join police officers in Parkersburg today to remember our fallen officers and pay tribute to those in uniform.

So many Vietnam veterans never received the thanks and appreciation they deserved when they returned home. It was an honor to present Dewey Thompson Jr. of Sophia today with the Purple Heart he earned during his service in the Marines in Vietnam. I worked with the Navy to help him receive the medals he deserved, and it was wonderful to see his family – including his granddaughter – at the Beckley Vet Center today to witness this ceremony.

One in five Americans will develop skin cancer – as we go into the summer months, don’t forget to wear sunscreen to lower your risk and reapply it often. West Virginia has so many beautiful parks and activities to enjoy, so keep you and your family safe while you’re having fun.
Too many Vietnam veterans came home and never got the thanks they deserved. We got to change that yesterday for Dewey Thompson Jr. WVVA has a look at what this Purple Heart means for his family.

We’ve seen firsthand in West Virginia how Lily's Place is treating newborns born exposed to heroin, opioids and other drugs. We need to make it easier for similar centers to open across the country to help the youngest victims of the drug crisis – newborn babies. I joined Congressman Mike Turner, Congresswoman Katherine Clark and Congressman Tim Ryan today to introduce bipartisan legislation, the CRIB Act, to make this a reality.

I met today with Parkersburg Police Chief Joseph Martin, president of the West Virginia Police Chiefs’ Association. We discussed the importance of maintaining funding for the High Intensity Drug Trafficking Program and other federal programs to combat the drug crisis. #PoliceWeek

I just voted to increase sanctions on companies that choose to do business with the Assad regime in Syria – sanctions send a strong message to Assad and the world that the slaughter of innocent civilians cannot and will not be tolerated. The Caesar Syria Civilian Protection Act, which I cosponsored, now goes to the Senate, and I hope they will take up this important bill soon.
The Huntington West Virginia Area Habitat for Humanity is leading the way in helping provide homes to veterans, thanks to its Veterans Housing Initiative.

This week is Police Week, where we honor and thank our officers for the sacrifices they make to keep us safe. Today, I helped pass the Thin Blue Line Act, which strengthens penalties for the murder or attempted murder of a police officer, firefighter or other first responder. Anyone who targets a first responder must be held accountable for their actions.

Today we are reminded of the sacrifices that our coal miners make everyday as we mourn the loss of Luches "Lou" Rosser, who was a husband, father, brother, and friend. Elizabeth and I are praying for comfort and peace for the Rosser family during this difficult time.

After nearly two years, we have a permanent VA clinic in Greenbrier County again. This clinic will help our veterans get care closer to home, and that’s why I fought for a commitment from the VA to reopen in Greenbrier.
Horrified by the news and images out of Manchester tonight -- please join me in praying for the victims and their families and friends.
The Congressional Coal Caucus met with EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt to discuss how we're rolling back the previous administration's anti-coal regulations so we can get our miners back to work.

Today I helped pass a number of bills to improve care for our veterans, including the Veterans Appeal Improvement and Modernization Act. This bill will help us start to reform the broken appeals process for our veterans by giving them more options in appealing their claims. I stand with our veterans and will continue to support legislation that works for them.
I really enjoyed giving Summers County High School’s AP Government class a behind-the-scenes tour of our Capitol.

It is an honor every year to be able to welcome the Always Free Honor Flight to our nation’s capital. Today, the veterans visited the World War II Memorial, and I was able to meet many of them and thank them for their service. The trip is also a wonderful opportunity for students to travel with veterans and hear their stories.

Today, I joined Rep. David McKinley in introducing the Miners Pension Protection Act, legislation to permanently secure miners’ pensions. Our miners deserve peace of mind after decades of hard work, and it’s time to keep the promise and protect the pensions they worked so hard to secure. We were able to get the job done for their healthcare benefits, and we must do the same for their pensions too.

Every child deserves to grow up safe and protected from those who wish to do them harm. This week in the House, we passed a number of bills to improve registering of sex offenders, make background checks more comprehensive, require sports organizations to report allegations of abuse, and ensure sex offenders who commit crimes overseas don’t escape prosecution when they come home.

On Memorial Day, we remember those who have made the ultimate sacrifice to defend our country, the freedoms we enjoy, and the liberties we cherish. I ask all West Virginians to join me in reflecting on the price of freedom and honoring those who gave their lives for our nation. May God bless our men and women in uniform and keep them safe, and may God bless America.

Thank you to the West Virginia School of Osteopathic Medicine for the honor of addressing your graduates this weekend. Physicians are a trusted pillar of our community and have the ability not only to heal sickness but to change lives. I congratulate our graduates and wish them all the best as they embark on their careers!

I had the honor of visiting Arlington Cemetery’s Tomb of the Unknown Soldier last week with several of my colleagues. As the father of a Marine, I am humbled and thankful for our men and women in uniform who have answered the call to serve our nation – and saddened for those who never made it home. As you enjoy this long weekend, please remember those who gave their lives so we can be free.

I offer my condolences to the family, friends and the Bluefield Police Department after the loss of an officer on duty overnight. We are grateful for the officer’s service and mourn this loss. Our officers know the risks and dangers they face every day, and we must never forget the sacrifices they make to keep us safe. Please join me in praying for the family of this officer and the Bluefield community.

I was invited to speak at a conference of local and state leaders in Wheeling today about best practices in addressing the drug crisis, including lessons learned from Huntington’s fight and my work to help establish Lily’s Place to treat babies born exposed to drugs during pregnancy.

Jan Vineyard was a beloved West Virginian, a proud Marshall graduate and supporter, and a wonderful friend and mother. She was known across our state for her work on behalf of West Virginia’s small businesses and employers. My prayers are with her family, and she will be missed.

Hardworking men and women across West Virginia – like those at Huntington Steel – are keeping our economy going and providing for their families. I’m honored to represent them in Congress and fight for solutions that will create more jobs and diversify our state’s economy. Thank you to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce for honoring me with the Spirit of Enterprise award during my visit to Huntington Steel.

After years of policies that put America second, we now have an administration and president focused on making America competitive again. President Trump is keeping his word by pulling us out of an agreement that was all pain, no gain for America’s workers, families and economy.   The Paris accord puts the United States on an uneven playing field, forcing us to make costly reductions all while countries like China and India make their own rules. The Obama administration has done enough damage to West Virginia’s jobs and our state’s way of life, and saying no to the Paris accord is saying no to Obama’s radical environmental and anti-jobs agenda.

The Regional Health Summit in Huntington brought together leaders from Kentucky, Ohio and West Virginia to share best practices. I discussed how we can work together to address the drug crisis and provide specialized care through innovative centers like Lily's Place.
Spent Saturday morning on the Guyandotte for the Guyandotte Water Trail dedication with the Lincoln County Cloggers. Cue Country Roads!

Beautiful day for the Military and Veterans Appreciation Picnic at Harris Riverfront Park in Huntington today. Thank you to all of our men and women in uniform and our veterans for their service to our nation!

Great day with Lincoln County residents as we dedicated the Branchland Park and opened the Guyandotte Water Trail. I presented a flag flown over the Capitol, which now flies over this park. The trail represents an important tourism project, which will give kayakers the opportunity to travel from Huntington all the way down to Wyoming County.

Companies like West Virginia Manufacturing in Alloy play a critical role in growing West Virginia’s economy. We can diversify our economy to attract more industries, jobs and opportunities to our great state.
The Hawks Nest Dam is an important regional project in southern West Virginia. I visited the site and met with their employees to learn more about their work.
Seventy-three years ago today, tens of thousands of brave Allied troops stormed Normandy to liberate Europe. We remember and honor their valor and sacrifices.

Today, I urged the director of the National Science Foundation to continue to work with other federal agencies in support of the Green Bank Observatory. This observatory and telescope are vitally important resources for West Virginia, giving students hands-on science education and conducting important research into our universe.

James Comey had clearly lost the trust of people in both parties, as well as that of the president himself. This investigation needs to be led by the facts, not politicians more focused on grabbing headlines and soundbites. I trust that Robert Mueller will conduct a thorough and fair review and present the facts that he finds.   I hope to see this president succeed and our state succeed – we have serious issues that need addressed, including jobs, unemployment, infrastructure, and the drug crisis.
I’m joining President Trump for a roundtable about transportation – I’m going to share with him our needs here in West Virginia. As go the roads, so go the jobs!

Investing in infrastructure isn’t just about building roads, it’s about getting our country moving again. Highways connect communities, keep drivers safer, and open up new business opportunities. I appreciated President Trump’s offer to join him today for his important announcement on cutting red tape for infrastructure investment, and I know his vision and leadership will produce results.
June is Alzheimer's Awareness Month, and the fifth annual Erma’s Angels Ride to End Alzheimer’s is raising both money and awareness to help cure this terrible disease.

Marshall University has decades of producing not only great doctors but caring for our community. I was pleased to join them for the grand opening of Marshall Health’s new center in Scott Depot, which will serve many eastern Cabell County residents.
I was honored to speak about miners’ safety and the importance of coal jobs at the annual Joseph A. Holmes Safety Association West Virginia State Council meeting.
I’m glad President Trump is getting the word out – mining jobs are coming back under his leadership!

The American Legion Mountaineer Boys State gives young men the opportunity to learn about leadership, citizenship and character. I had the opportunity to speak to these outstanding students today and am confident they will be part of the next generation of leaders in West Virginia.

As a father, it’s devastating to hear of children who have been victimized by predators, whether they be strangers or trusted coaches or mentors. My colleagues and I in the U.S. House of Representatives are taking action to protect our children and give law enforcement the tools they need to keep our children safe and stop sex offenders.

We’re seeing more and more mines reopening and staffing up, thanks to this administration’s pro-coal jobs policies. Three job fairs will be held for a new mine opening in Raleigh County – please share and spread the word.

I’m asking Education Secretary Betsy DeVos to reconsider the applications of West Virginia University and West Virginia State University for much-needed funds for first-generation college students. WVU and WVSU’s applications were denied due to minor, unintentional clerical errors, and hardworking students should not be punished and denied the opportunity for an education because of unintentional errors.
I appreciate President Trump's continued support of our coal jobs and our state.
Please join me in praying for my friend Congressman Steve Scalise, aides, Capitol Police and everyone at this morning's Congressional Baseball Game practice.

Please join me in praying for the family, friends and fellow miners of Rodney Osborne of Artie. Mining is a tough, hazardous job, and we honor and remember the work our miners do and support our community of miners and mining families.

As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I have the opportunity to advocate for West Virginia’s priorities in each year’s funding bills. This afternoon, I helped to pass billions in investments in veterans health care in the Fiscal Year 2018 VA budget bill. That includes $250 million especially for rural health initiatives and $8.4 billion for mental health care services. This bill now goes to the House floor for a vote, and I will be proud to see this bill go to the president’s desk.

West Virginia is blessed with many natural resources -- including coal and natural gas -- but we will never unlock our full potential if the harmful, job-killing policies of the Obama administration keep holding us back. I had a chance to share that message with EPA Administrator Scott Pruitt yesterday.

Healthcare experts from WVU and other major Appalachia universities came to Capitol Hill today to present their research on how we can best address the opioid crisis. I was pleased to be able to join them for this important discussion and encourage everyone to work together to solve this epidemic.

Otto Warmbier was a college student with his whole life ahead of him, and the treatment he suffered at the hands of North Korea is nothing short of barbaric. America stands with the entire Warmbier family and prays for them during this heartbreaking time.
Happy birthday, West Virginia! We’re a special state with the best people anywhere in this country, and I’m proud to call West Virginia my home. #AlmostHeaven

I voted to pass legislation that will improve and streamline child and foster care programs. These are good, bipartisan bills that will help states protect children and provide more support for families.
Tonight we're celebrating Marshall University, one of our state's great institutions. Go Herd!

One year ago today, we experienced one of the darkest days in our state’s history. We thank those who put their lives on the line to help rescue others; we remember and honor those whom we lost; we continue to offer our support to those rebuilding their lives. That’s what we do as neighbors. That’s what we do as friends. That’s what we do as West Virginians.

Four of the highest overdose counties in the entire country are in the Third District, and having an FBI office here would help coordinate and strengthen law enforcement efforts to stop drug trafficking. I had the opportunity to talk with the FBI’s acting director about this yesterday, and he said the FBI is actively discussing reopening its Beckley office.
The Supreme Court’s decision today is good news for our national security. President Trump’s plan will make us safer and help keep out those who wish to do us harm.
This is great news for West Virginia – the RECLAIM Act will help us diversify our economy and bring new jobs to our state. I’m proud to be a cosponsor of this important bill.

I'm proud to stand with my colleagues on the Bipartisan Heroin Task Force to address drug treatment, prescribing and trafficking. I shared how my bill, the CRIB Act, will help us treat drug-exposed newborns all across the country. Solving this crisis will require all of us to work together.

The Trump administration has halted the Waters of the United States rule, one of most damaging, job-killing rules from the Obama era. This rule threatened the jobs of farmers, miners and small businesses in West Virginia and across the nation. I fought in Congress for two years to pass legislation and cut the EPA’s budget to block this rule, and I applaud President Trump for his leadership in acting to protect American jobs.
It was an honor to welcome Rep. Karen Handel, our newest member of Congress, on her first full day on the job on Tuesday.

Too many families are waiting for justice for their loved ones. This week, we’ll take up legislation to increase immigration enforcement and stop sanctuary cities from harboring dangerous illegal immigrants who have committed crimes.

This morning, I had the honor of joining Sergeant Major of the Army Daniel Dailey and our brave men and women in uniform for a run on the National Mall. With us was Private First Class Cody Muncy of Boone County, and it was my privilege to be able to spend some time with this great West Virginian and thank him for his service.

Just a few minutes ago, I cast votes to pass Kate’s Law and to stop sanctuary cities from protecting illegal immigrants who’ve committed crimes. This is about the rule of law – and keeping Americans safe.
Brave men and women of the West Virginia Air National Guard have been deployed to Afghanistan and Southwest Asia to protect our nation. Please join me in praying for their safe return.

While our troops are protecting our nation across the world, we must make sure they have the funding, equipment and resources necessary to get the job done. I was proud to vote this week in the House Appropriations Committee to provide much-needed funding for our troops to complete their missions and defeat ISIS. The bill includes a pay raise for our men and women in uniform – a small way to say thank you for all their work to keep our country safe.
Happy birthday to the United States of America, the greatest country in the world! We are blessed to live in a nation dedicated to freedom and liberty.

Veterans in Nicholas, Pocahontas and Webster counties now have access to VA care closer to home, thanks to this new clinic we opened today. As an appropriator, I'm committed to fighting for the funding needed to care for all of our veterans and hold the VA accountable.
As a member of the VA Appropriations Subcommittee that oversees VA operations and funding, I visited the Clarksburg VA hospital today to hear from veterans about what is and isn't working for them.

North Korea’s missile test is a threat to not only our national security but that of our allies. President Trump is right: China needs to step up pressure on North Korea to stop its tests, not support the regime through increased trade.

The flags at St. Joseph Central Catholic High School in Huntington were in disrepair and ready to be retired. State Senator Mike Woelfel donated a West Virginia flag, and I brought an American flag. These new flags will fly proudly over the school for the new school year.

As a member of the House Appropriations VA Subcommittee, I’m working to making sure our VA is meeting the needs of our rural and our female veterans. This new VA clinic in South Charleston is saving many Third District veterans from having to drive to Huntington. It also provides specialized services for female veterans, addressing a critical gap in care.

As a member of the House Appropriations VA Subcommittee, oversight of VA operations is a critical part of my work on the committee. Today I met with veterans at the VA clinic in Parkersburg to hear their thoughts on how the VA can serve them better.

If you are looking for a job, please join us for a job fair in Bluefield on Monday. You’ll have the opportunity to meet with dozens of employers, so bring your resumes and credentials. The event will be held from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. at the Bluefield Auditorium. Please share so we can spread the word!
Meeting with members of the Tri-State India Association about their legislative priorities and the needs of Huntington’s Indian community.

It’s a beautiful day in Barboursville for lunch with our World War II, Korea and Vietnam veterans. This Honor Flight Reunion Picnic gives our veterans a chance to catch up – and us a chance to say thanks for their service.
Don't miss the Bluefield Job Fair tomorrow! You can meet with dozens of local employers from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. Monday at the Bluefield Auditorium. Be sure to bring your resume and credentials.
Today’s job fair in Bluefield was a success! We connected a lot of job seekers with potential employers, and I appreciate everyone who joined us today for this important event.
Today I toured Bluefield State College's engineering school and saw firsthand how their manufacturing programs are equipping our students with the skills they need to compete in the workforce.

What a wonderful, patriotic welcome from the residents and staff at Princeton Healthcare Center! I was proud to present them with an American flag flown over the U.S. Capitol to fly in front of their building.
As go the roads, so go the jobs. It’s time for Charleston to invest in Southern West Virginia and complete long-promised roads like the King Coal Highway!

At today’s Ceredo-Kenova Business Association lunch, we discussed how we can reinvest in Wayne County, promote projects like the Heartland Intermodal Gateway in Prichard to create jobs, and get the Tolsia Highway connected to Southern West Virginia.

Today, I voted to fund the Appalachian Regional Commission and to reject the proposed elimination of this vital program. The ARC is making a difference every day in communities throughout West Virginia. As our state struggles to recover from eight years of devastating economic policies, we need programs like the ARC more than ever.

Human trafficking isn’t just happening in other countries. It’s happening right here in America, even in West Virginia. We’ve just passed legislation today that will help quickly identify victims of trafficking, stop the human trafficking trade and help local law enforcement respond to this crisis.

Southern WV veterans – join my office at Saturday’s Veterans Expo at the Raleigh County Convention Center from 10 a.m. to 2 p.m. The VA will be offering assistance with claims, education, employment, and VA services, as well as on-site healthcare screenings. Please share!

I’ve fought successfully to restore funding for important programs to stop drug trafficking and help communities combat the opioid crisis. WOWK 13 NEWS has a look at how this money will make a difference right here in West Virginia.
Bringing back coal jobs creates more opportunities in other industries too! This equipment manufacturer is bringing back laid-off employees to meet the demand as coal mines ramp up production.

Thank you to the American Legion for the invitation to speak at this morning's convention in Huntington. I shared how I voted this week to roll back the previous administration's cuts to our military so our troops have the resources they need to defend our nation and keep us safe.

Stopped by the Pullman Square Farmers Market and met with farmers from the Wayne County Farmers Co-Op. Local farms and farmers markets work hand in hand to get fresh, healthy food into our communities. I'll continue to support programs like these that open up new markets for West Virginia agriculture.

The National Energy Technology Laboratory is leading the way in researching new ways to use our coal and natural gas reserves. It also employs 611 people in Morgantown, making it a major regional employer. I worked to save the NETL to protect these jobs and ensure this important research continues.
I’m saddened to hear of the passing of Concord Assistant Football Coach Pat Dawson and send my thoughts and prayers to his family, friends, colleagues and the Concord community.

Please join me for a job fair on Aug. 3 and meet with a variety of employers from West Virginia and Kentucky, including coal operators, manufacturers and hospitals. We’ll also have career counselors on hand to help you with your resume and interview skills. I’m happy to be sponsoring this great event with Congressman Hal Rogers – please share and spread the word!

Through my role on the House Appropriations Committee, I'm fighting to protect life and make sure that taxpayer dollars are not going to pay for abortions. I just supported the Aderholt amendment, which does just that by making sure federal funds aren't paying for abortions at Immigrations and Customs Enforcement facilities. We prevailed by a 29-22 vote -- this is an important vote on an important issue.

Thousands of Boy Scouts are stopping in our nation's capital on their way to the National Boy Scouts Jamboree in West Virginia, including these troops from Texas and Minnesota. I've been telling them how beautiful our state is and how wonderful the people are – I love showing them the way to the Mountain State.

As Americans, the security of our nation must come first. That’s why I fought to ensure we funded President Trump’s full request of $1.6 billion for the border wall, and I’m pleased to have voted this funding out of the House Appropriations Committee just a few minutes ago. The funding I helped secure will allow us to strengthen our national security and curb illegal immigration.
More good news for coal and West Virginia jobs during President Trump’s first six months in office!

The Democrats today tried to restore funding for Planned Parenthood, an effort we successfully blocked. This money instead needs to go to our community health centers, which are located all over West Virginia and provide important healthcare services to thousands of women.
John McCain is a true American hero -- and a fighter. Please join me in praying for him and his family.

We're still working tonight in the House Appropriations Committee. The Democrats keep trying to restore funding for abortion providers, but I'm standing up for life and helping to defeat these amendments.

Through my work on the House Appropriations Committee, I’ve helped cut the EPA’s budget by more than half a billion dollars. While it’s important that we continue critical investments to improve our air and water, it’s imperative that Congress stop funding anti-coal regulations. I’m working with my colleagues and President Trump to cut wasteful spending at the EPA while still protecting the EPA’s core functions.

Congresswoman Jaime Herrera Beutler saw her daughter survive against incredible odds, and she wants to give little Charlie Gard that same chance. I was proud to support her amendment to offer residency to Charlie and his parents so they can continue their fight for his life in the United States.

I'm using my role on the House Appropriations Committee to fight for West Virginia's priorities. That includes securing funding for black lung clinics to care for our miners and substance abuse treatment to help people find recovery from opioids and heroin.

I am honored to welcome President Trump to the great state of West Virginia for his first visit as president. He visited our state a year ago to hear our concerns -- and now as president, he's fighting for us. I look forward to working with him to continue to create jobs and bring opportunities back to our state and the people who call West Virginia home.
If you had the chance to ask or say one thing to President Trump when he visits West Virginia tomorrow, what would it be?
We’re ready to welcome President Trump to West Virginia and the National Jamboree!
It’s been 12 years since a president has attended the National Jamboree, but President Trump is here during his first year!

I am deeply disappointed that Senate Democrats like Joe Manchin refused to even start debate on the healthcare bill. For all their talk about working across the aisle and with our president, we see now that when it comes time to act, they refuse to come to the table.   Whether they want to acknowledge it or not, Obamacare is failing. West Virginia families on the exchanges have seen their premiums increase by 169 percent since 2013, all while deductibles are rising and insurers are fleeing. Senate Democrats now face a choice: They can either be part of the solution or they can stand idly by while our healthcare system collapses.

This is some much-needed good news about Congressman Steve Scalise! I’m proud to call Steve a colleague and a friend, and my continued prayers are with him and everyone wounded that terrible day as they continue their rehabilitation and recovery.
NA
Before you attend our job fair next Thursday, Aug. 3, at Belfry High School, get help this Friday to get your resume ready to go!

I’m pleased to share that I’ve helped secure more than $42 million in new federal funding to help us recover from last year’s floods. The federal government was using outdated data from FEMA to calculate West Virginia’s disaster assistance, so I wrote to HUD Secretary Ben Carson and FEMA asking them to use the most recent data. When they looked at the new data, West Virginia qualified for more federal flood aid. I’m proud to fight for West Virginia’s priorities and our fair share of funding.

I’m proud to support the Make America Secure Appropriations Act, which we just passed in the House. As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, I helped write this bill, which funds the construction of the border wall, provides healthcare for our veterans, gives our troops a pay raise, and saves the Appalachian Regional Commission. I hope the Senate will send this bill to President Trump soon so he can sign it into law.

I am deeply disappointed that the Senate failed to continue their work to repeal and replace Obamacare. The status quo simply isn’t acceptable. Since 2013, West Virginia has seen some of the highest premium increases in the country – 169 percent. In fact, we saw just this week how unsustainable Obamacare is financially when the Charleston Area Medical Center announced it would have to eliminate 300 jobs. This was our best opportunity to make real, meaningful reforms to our healthcare system, and those who stood in the way of even bipartisan debate on this critical issue must explain why they protected the Obama administration’s failed legacy.

I'm heartbroken to see West Virginia families and communities devastated by flooding and storm damage. I've reached out to our state officials to see how I can help in their efforts working with the dedicated local first responders to help those in need. On the House Appropriations Committee, I oversee FEMA's funding, and I'm ready to work to make sure we get the federal assistance we need.

West Virginia’s hospitals are working to address a rising number of babies born with neonatal abstinence syndrome – exposure to drugs during pregnancy. Newborns are truly the most innocent victims of the opioid crisis sweeping our state and our nation. I visited Thomas Memorial Hospital today to see how their NICU is responding and met with doctors, nurses and administrators to discuss how we can work together to expand models of care for these babies.

I fought to save the National Energy Technology Laboratory – and its more than 600 West Virginia jobs – because of its important research into new uses and opportunities for coal. I visited the NETL in Morgantown today to learn more about their work on storage hubs and how this can open up new markets for coal.

Don't forget -- Join me for a job fair tomorrow, Aug. 3, and meet with a number of employers from West Virginia and Kentucky, including coal operators, manufacturers and hospitals. We’ll also have career counselors on hand to help you with your resume and interview skills. I’m happy to be sponsoring this great event with Congressman Hal Rogers – please share and spread the word!

The Bluefield Daily Telegraph looks at how coal and energy are driving West Virginia’s economy: “The war on coal has ended, and we have an administration in Washington that is embracing coal, natural gas and other fossil fuels. This can only help West Virginia.”

Our veterans deserve the best care possible. I’m using my oversight role on the House Appropriations Committee’s Veterans Affairs subcommittee to make sure our VA facilities are providing the quality, timely care our veterans have earned.
A great turnout for today’s Tug Valley Job Fair -- thank you to everyone who joined Congressman Hal Rogers and me for this important event. A good job solves a lot of problems!

Tech. Sgt. David Board of Barboursville made the ultimate sacrifice for our nation, and we are profoundly thankful for his service and heartbroken over his passing. Please join me in praying for this brave West Virginian, his family, his friends, and the entire 130th Wing.

The White Sulphur Springs National Fish Hatchery was hit hard in last year's floods, but they are restocking and well on their way to recovery. I fought hard to make sure this hatchery got the funding and support they needed to rebuild, and I'm happy to see them back in operation.
I joined county commissioners from across West Virginia today to talk about how I'm working to create more jobs, grow our economy, and invest in our roads and bridges.

Please join me for the Ohio Valley Regional Job Fair in Point Pleasant on Tuesday, Aug. 15! I’ll be there along with a number of employers from West Virginia and Ohio, as well as career counselors to help you with your resume and interview skills. Please bring your certifications and resume and be ready to meet with potential employers. The event will be held at the Trinity United Methodist Church Community Building, 615 Viand St., from 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Hope to see you there!
